titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Press of the Woolly Whale Records
Press of the Woolly Whale Records
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:20

did.unittitle: Press of the Woolly Whale records

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection primarily consists of correspondence and production files related to publications issued by the Press of the Woolly Whale, including original and carbon typescripts, corrected page proofs and galleys, paper samples, title page and endpaper designs, dummies, notes, and receipts. Some of the production files hold original artwork for illustrations; also present are four photoengravings used to print endpapers for Melbert B. Cary's two-volume work Mademoiselle from Armentieres. In addition, the records contain the press's archival set of Woolly Whale publications including ephemeral items such as prospectuses, invitations, broadsides, holiday cards, mailing labels, and certificates, as well as four chronologically arranged scrapbooks created by Cary to hold samples of ephemera, reviews of the press's work, and other clippings. For his productions Cary employed favorite artists such as Alban B. Butler, Warren Chappell, W. A. Dwiggins, Willi Harweth, Fritz Kredel, and Philip G. Reed, and authors including Richard Le Gallienne; several of the volumes in the press copies set have bespoke bindings by prominent hand binders Katharine Adams, Douglas Cockerell & Son, Peter Franck, Otto Fratzscher, and Gerhard Gerlach. Other correspondents in the collection include Paul and Rudolf Koch, Robert Winslow Gordon, and firms such as Gebrüder Klingspor.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 58: Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Mary Flagler Cary Charitable Trust, 1969.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Press of the Woolly Whale Records is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Press of the Woolly Whale Records. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Former call number: Uncat MS Vault Woolly

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Melbert B. Cary Graphic Arts Collection at Rochester Institute of Technology holds additional Press of the Woolly Whale records including production files (CSC 023) and the press's visitor register (CSC 022).

bioghist.head: Press of the Woolly Whale
bioghist.p: The Press of the Woolly Whale was in operation in New York City from 1928 to 1942, during which time it produced private and limited edition volumes, publications related to printing and typographic arts, and a wide variety of ephemera that reflected the interests, professional relationships, and personal humor of Melbert Brinkerhoff Cary Jr., his wife Mary Flagler Cary, and their friends. While Cary directed the press's efforts, he employed George W. Van Vechten Jr. for typesetting and press work. Two exhibitions profiled the press's achievements (Grosvenor Library, Buffalo, New York, in 1939, and Rochester Institute of Technology in 1972); the catalogs from those exhibitions contained bibliographies which were superseded by David Pankow's checklist in Melbert B. Cary, Jr. and the Press of the Woolly Whale (Rochester: Cary Graphic Arts Press, Rochester Institute of Technology, 2002).

bioghist.head: Melbert B. Cary Jr. and Mary Flagler Cary
bioghist.p: Melbert Brinkerhoff Cary Jr. (1892-1941), a New York businessman and prominent figure in the fields of typography and private printing during the second quarter of the twentieth century, was born in New York, the son of Melbert and Julia Metcalf Cary. Educated at the Groton School and Yale University (Class of 1916), he served in France with the American Expeditionary Forces during World War I. Cary was the director of the Continental Typefounders Association, Inc., which he organized in New York City in 1925 to import from Europe the best new designs in type, initials, borders, and ornaments being developed by foundries on the continent, but cast to American type height and using the American point system so that designers and printers in the United States could use fresh and modern faces for commercial advertising.

In 1923 Cary married Mary Harkness Flagler (1901-1967), the daughter of Anne Lamont and Harry Harkness Flagler, and the granddaughter of Henry Morrison Flagler, one of the founders of the Standard Oil Company. She was raised in New York City and in Millbrook, New York, where the Carys continued to maintain homes after their marriage. Melbert Cary Jr. served as president of the American Institute of Graphic Arts, was proprietor of the private Press of the Woolly Whale, and a collector of printer's manuals and type specimens, great books of the printer's art, and rare playing cards; he acquired the Kelmscott/Goudy Press (Albion No. 6551) on which William Morris had printed The Works of Geoffrey Chauce r (1896), from Frederic W. Goudy in 1932. Mary Flagler Cary was the president of the National Orchestral Association and a collector of rare manuscript music.

bioghist.head: George W. Van Vechten Jr.
bioghist.p: George W. Van Vechten Jr., American printer, typographer, and book designer, was born in New Brunswick, New Jersey, attended Carnegie Institute of Technology, and died in Metuchen, New Jersey, in 1962, at age 55. He produced private and limited edition works for thirty-five years with Frederic W. Goudy at the Village Press, with Melbert B. Cary Jr. at the Press of the Woolly Whale, and from 1941 to 1962 at his own Van Vechten Press in Metuchen. Van Vechten inherited the Kelmscott/Goudy Press (Albion No. 6551) upon Cary's death in 1941.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records primarily consist of correspondence and production files related to work created at the Press of the Woolly Whale, including original and carbon typescripts, corrected page proofs and galleys, paper samples, title page and endpaper designs, dummies, notes, and receipts. Some of the production files hold original artwork for illustrations; also present are four photoengravings used to print endpapers for Melbert B. Cary's two-volume work Mademoiselle from Armentieres . In addition, the records contain the press's archival set of Woolly Whale publications including ephemeral items such as prospectuses, invitations, broadsides, holiday cards, mailing labels, and certificates, as well as four chronologically arranged scrapbooks created by Cary to hold samples of small ephemera, reviews of the press's work, and other related clippings. Many of the Woolly Whale publications were produced as holiday, anniversary, and birthday greetings, and tributes to respected colleagues, particularly Frederic W. Goudy. A military veteran, Cary issued annual tributes to Armistice Day beginning in 1928 ranging in format from a simple broadside to a set of playing cards, The Devil's Bible .

For his productions Cary employed favorite artists such as Alban B. Butler, Warren Chappell, W. A. Dwiggins, Willi Harwerth, Fritz Kredel, and Philip G. Reed, and authors including Richard Le Gallienne; several of the volumes in the press copies set have bespoke bindings by prominent hand binders Katharine Adams, Douglas Cockerell & Son, Peter Franck, Otto Fratzscher, and Gerhard Gerlach. Other correspondents in the collection include Paul and Rudolf Koch, Robert Winslow Gordon, and firms such as Gebrüder Klingspor.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence and Papers, 1893-1968. II. Scrapbooks, 1928-1942. III. Production Files, 1928-1942. IV. Press of the Woolly Whale Publications, 1928-1942.

did.unittitle: Correspondence and Papers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into four subseries: Melbert B. Cary Papers, Mary Flagler Cary Papers, Inventories, and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains general correspondence files regarding the press and printing, and a group of publications stock inventories made after Melbert Cary's death. Also filed here are original designs considered for the Woolly Whale pressmark. Other Papers contains publications found with the Woolly Whale records but not produced by the press, including copies of the catalogue from the first exhibition of the press's work. Correspondence related to specific publications and other press projects is in Series III, Production Files.

did.unittitle: Melbert B. Cary Papers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged under two headings: Correspondence, and Subject Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains four volumes of scrapbooks, specially bound in stamped calf and enclosed in titled slipcases, that were created to hold material by and about the Press of the Woolly Whale. Each contains samples of printed ephemera produced by the press such as stationery, invitations, luggage tags, mailing labels, postcards, and pamphlets, as well as clippings from newspapers and trade journals regarding publications of the press. A fifth scrapbook had a detached spine and front cover, and no slipcase; the material within had only been laid in between the first few pages in the front of the volume so it was removed and foldered, and the scrapbook discarded. Additional copies of material found in the scrapbooks may also appear in Series IV, Press of the Woolly Whale Publications.

Scrapbook 2

Production Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains files related to the production of publications issued by the press, including correspondence, notes, original artwork, paper samples, dummies, mechanicals, and proofs. As the projects were primarily of Cary's own creation few of the files contain correspondence, but there are exceptions. Two such publications are (41) Mademoiselle from Armentieres , vol. II, and (47) Estivation of Two Mao Tzu which both have correspondence and research materials. The first contains versions of the songs Cary collected from veterans and others, correspondence with Robert Winslow Gordon of the Library of Congress Music Division's Archive of Folk Song, and an article Cary published in the Journal of American Folklore 47 (1934); the second has correspondence with scholar Chi-Chen Wang and with Carroll T. Harris, Cary's typesetter for the book. Many of the files hold original drawings used for illustrations, particularly the work of Alban Butler Jr., and the files for (37) Some Thoughts on the Ornamented Mss. of the Middle Ages contain multiple photographs by Arnold Genthe of the Kelmscott/Goudy Press (Albion No. 6551) plus Warren Chappell's drawing after one of those images.

The projects are arranged by the checklist number established in David Pankow's annotated bibliography Melbert B. Cary, Jr. and the Press of the Woolly Whale (2002), which is arranged chronologically. There is not a file for every project; numbers in brackets indicate the items that do not appear in the bibliography. Filed at the end of the series is work accomplished for organizations with which the Carys were closely involved, projects contemplated but not completed, and unidentified artwork.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series primarily contains publications, both volumes and ephemera, that were produced at the Press of the Woolly Whale. Most of the volumes were labeled "Press Copy," though also kept here are copies created with special papers, inks, coloring, or variant bindings, and some with slipcases or bespoke containers. Exemplars, among others are: (57) The Ninth Man , hand-colored by Fritz Kredel; (96) Gutenberg and the Strasbourg Documents of 1439 , bound by Gerhard Gerlach; (98) The Missing Gutenberg Wooden Blocks , bound by Peter Franck; (16) And It Came to Pass , a small Christmas greeting bound by Otto Fratzscher; and (37) Some Thoughts on the Ornamented Mss. of the Middle Ages , by William Morris, for which there are copies bound by six different binders. One copy of (28) Stille Nacht, Heilige Nacht: A Christmas Song is annoted "This is the only copy composed of untreated sheets. All others have been dipped in coffee after printing." There are also are special association copies signed by the authors or others, including (21) The Sentimental Bloke , by C. J. Dennis, which was inscribed by Cary using his family nickname: "for Mary -- to whom the original Sentimental Bloke was sent way back in 1922. Mike."

The publications are arranged by the checklist number established in David Pankow's annotated bibliography Melbert B. Cary, Jr. and the Press of the Woolly Whale (2002), which is arranged chronologically; numbers in brackets indicate the items that do not appear in the bibliography. Copies of ephemeral items can also be found in Series II, Scrapbooks. Filed at the end of the series is work accomplished for organizations with which the Carys were closely involved; after Cary became president of the American Institute of Graphic Arts (AIGA) the press printed several ephemeral publications for the group.
The copies of publications in this series are not recorded in Orbis, the library's online catalog.
